Summary: starlike object just off the coast then shot almost straight up like a missile.
divs: sighting detailsi live just north of downtown st. augustine florida, approx. a quarter mile inland (west) of the inter-coastal waterway. roughly the same distance to the northeast, lies the southern tip of st. augustine airport's runway, so i'm well familiar with all the aircraft in the area, and i also carry an interest in aviation in general. i'm used to seeing the private jets taking off to the east-southeast, the tourist helicopters flying in overhead to land an refuel, the high flying passenger liners heading north\south (or vice versa) on their way to and from jacksonville, and i've even witnessed more than a handful of satellites circling the earth, just before daylight in the morning and after dusk at night. but then this morning, approximately 5:00 am, i finally saw something i can't explain away as normal. i initially spotted the object and wrote it off for a moment as a bright morning star. it sat stationary, due east, at about 20 degrees above the horizon. i know that just to the east-southeast lies the vilano bridge, so i'm not sure if it was over land or water, but i would estimate that the craft was again due east, at roughly a mile to a mile and a half's distance, possibly two. the reason that i recognized the vessel was indeed much closer than a low hanging star, is because my eye was again drawn to it by a brief pulse or flash of light, (almost like a tomahawk cruise missile had been fired - only silently) as it began immediately ascending near vertically, leaving a trail nearly identical to that of a falling star, only on the incline, rather than the decline. it's ascent, again near vertically, was toward the west-northwest, and it flew just behind the fingertip of a cloud (as a rain front was preparing to move through) then i finally lost sight of it behind a tree, a big cloud, and the corner of the roof of my porch. while it's entire ascent was quick (taking 2-3 seconds) its rate if climb wasn't instantaneous, and the object seemed to accelerate throughout its journey. so the blueish-purple tail was the most prominent feature, but just above this remained the whitish light that i had originally mistaken as a star, and atop this, (mind you the craft seemed a bit blurred together by the bright white light) looked to be what i could best describe as half a bubble. the outside edges of the bubble were white like the light, but the middle was the same dull midnight blue as the sky.
trends: There have been 18 other sightings in St Augustine
There was one other sighting in St Augustine on or around October 7th 2011
